stars.description: O-type stars, also reffered to as white supergiants are the most luminous and massive stars in the galaxy. They reach temperatures ranging between 30,000K and 50,000K.
B-type stars, also reffered to as blue-white supergiants are very luminous and blue. They reach temperatures in range between 10,000K and 30,000K.
A-type stars, also reffered to as blue giants are young, white or bluish-white stars. They reach temeperatures ranging between 7600K and 10,000K.
F-type stars, also reffered to as yellow-white dwarfs are hydrogen-fusing stars with temperatures ranging between 6000K and 7600K.
G-type stars, also reffered to as yellow dwarfs are hydrogen-fusing stars with temperatures ranging between 5300K and 6000K.
K-type stars, also reffered to as orange dwarfs are hydrogen-fusing stars with temperatures ranging beteween 3500K and 5300K.

C-type stars, also reffered to as carbon stars, are stars whose atmospheres contain more carbon than oxygen, giving the star a sooty atmosphere and a strikingly ruby red appearance. They reach temperatures between 2500K and 3500K.
M-type stars, also reffered to as red dwarfs are the smallest and coolest kinds of stars in the main sequence. They reach temperatures between 2000K and 2500K.
L-type stars, also reffered to as brown dwarfs, are small, very dark red in color stars. They reach temperatures between only 500K and 700K.

Neutron stars are the stellar remnants of massive stars that have reached the end of their lives. Once nuclear fusion was exhausted, the star collapsed into a tiny volume, and thus created a neutron star.
